にくい.name: にくい (nikui)
にくい.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: にくい (nikui). Meaning: difficult to do~.

,

This is used to say that it is difficult to do something.

,

Add にくい to the verb’s stem form to say that action is difficult to do.

,

To say the opposite, that something is “easy to do”, use やすい (yasui) instead.

,

Click the image to download the flashcard.
Download all N4 grammar flashcards.

,

Download our complete
JLPT N4 Grammar Master E-book.

examples.en: This question is difficult to answer.
examples.ja: この質問には答えにくいです。

examples.en: This books print is too small, it's difficult to read.
examples.ja: この本は字が小さくて読みにくいです。

examples.en: This kanji is difficult to remember.
examples.ja: この漢字は覚えにくいです。

examples.en: This bicycle is old and difficult to ride.
examples.ja: この自転車は古くて乗りにくいです。

examples.en: Fish have a bunch of bones and are difficult to eat.
examples.ja: 魚は骨が多くて食べにくいだ。

examples.en: His explanation was complicated and difficult to understand.
examples.ja: 彼の説明が難しくて分かりにくいだった。

examples.en: This road is really narrow, and there's lots of cars, so it's difficult to drive on.
examples.ja: この道は狭くて、車も多いので、運転しにくいです。

examples.en: She's a difficult person to get along with.
examples.ja: 彼女はつき合いにくい人だ。

ございます.name: ございます (gozaimasu)
ございます.definition: to be, to exist (the polite form of いる/ある)

Learn Japanese grammar: ございます (gozaimasu). Meaning: to be, to exist (the polite form of いる/ある).

始める（はじめる）.name: 始める (hajimeru)
始める（はじめる）.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: 始める 【はじめる】 (hajimeru). Meaning: to start; to begin to~.

,

This is used to express when something is starting or has just begun. It can be freely conjugated to use in current, future, and past tense.

,

Download all N4 grammar flashcards.

,

Download our complete
JLPT N4 Grammar Master E-book.

examples.en: I still haven't started cooking dinner.

examples.ja: この状況は変わり始めている。

はずだ.name: はずだ (hazu da)
はずだ.definition: it must be; it should be (expectation)
はずだ.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: はずだ (hazu da). Meaning: it must be; it should be (expectation).

,

To say the opposite, “it cannot be..”, use はずがない (hazu ga nai).

はずがない.name: はずがない (hazu ga nai)
はずがない.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: はずがない (hazu ga nai). Meaning: cannot be (impossible).

,

This is used to strongly emphasize that something cannot be or is impossible.

,

To say the opposite, use はずだ (hazu da) instead.

てくる.name: てくる (te kuru)
てくる.definition: to do… and come back; to become; to continue; to start~
てくる.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: てくる (te kuru) / てきみます (te kimasu). Meaning: to do… and come back; to become, to continue, to start~.

,

This can be used to express various meanings.

,

This is used after a verb to express a continued change in state, usually for something that moves toward the speaker (not necessarily a physical movement).

,

For something that moves away from the speaker, instead use ていく (te iku).

,

This grammar requires the use of て form. If you don’t know how to conjugate it, you can reference this table.

,

If you already know how to use て form, skip down to the examples.

,

Download all N4 grammar flashcards.

,

JLPT N4 Grammar Master E-book.

It is often used with に to show who you’re requesting to do the task.

必要がある（ひつようがある）.name: 必要がある (hitsuyou ga aru)
必要がある（ひつようがある）.definition: need to; it is necessary to
必要がある（ひつようがある）.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: 必要がある 【ひつようがある】(hitsuyou ga aru). Meaning: that one needs to do something; that it is necessary to do something.

,

必要 (hitsuyou) means necessary/necessity and がある (ga aru) means there is, so it literally translates to there is a necessity to…

,

私はもっと勉強する必要がある。

,

watashi wa motto benkyou suru hitsuyou ga aru.

,

I need to study more.

,

今日は事務所に行く必要がない。

,

kyou wa jimusho ni iku hitsuyou ga nai.

,

There is no need to go into the office today.

,

To be more polite, you can use 必要があります (hitsuyou ga arimasu) and 必要がありません (hitsuyou ga arimasen) instead.

,

私は大丈夫ですよ。あなたには何もする必要がありません。

,

watashi wa daijoubu desu yo. anata ni wa nanimo suru hitsuyou ga arimasen.

,

I’m fine. There’s no need for you to do anything.

,

,

てしまう / ちゃう.name: てしまう / ちゃう (te shimau / chau)
てしまう / ちゃう.definition: to do something by accident, to finish completely
てしまう / ちゃう.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: てしまう (te shimau) & ちゃう (chau). Meaning: to do something by accident, to finish completely.

,

This may in some cases also express regret, but not always.

,

This is the standard version:

,

This is the more casual version, which instead uses a verb’s stem form:

,

NOTE: If the verb’s dictionary form ends with ぶ (bu) , む (mu) , ぬ (nu) or ぐ (gu), it becomes じゃう (jau) or じゃった (jatta).

Learn Japanese grammar: いらっしゃる (irassharu). Meaning: to be; to come; to go.

意向形 （いこうけい）.name: 意向形  (ikou kei - volitional form)
意向形 （いこうけい）.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: 意向形 【いこうけい】(ikou kei). Meaning: volitional form​; let’s do ~.

,

This grammar turns verbs from statements into suggestions.

,

Remove the final る (ru) syllable and replace it with よう (you).

,

食べる → 食べよう (taberu → tabeyou) let’s eat

,

To be more polite, add ましょう (mashou) instead.

,

食べる → 食べましょう (taberu → tabemashou) let’s eat

,

Change the final vowel to (o) and add a singular (u) to the end.

,

読む → 読もう (yomu → yomou) let’s read

,

買う → 買おう (kau → kaou) let’s buy

,

To be more polite, change the final vowel to (i) and add ましょう (mashou) to the end.

,

読む → 読みましょう (yomu → yomimashou) let’s read

,

買う → 買いましょう (kau → kaimashou) let’s buy

,

する → しよう (suru → shiyou) let’s do..

,

する → しましょう (suru → shimashou) let’s do..

,

来る → 来よう (kuru → koyou) let’s come/go

,

来る → 来ましょう (kuru → kimashou) let’s come/go

,

Download all N4 grammar flashcards.

られる.name: られる (rareru)
られる.definition: potential form; ability or inability to do something
られる.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: られる (rareru). Meaning: potential form; being able to do something.

,

This is used to describe the ability or inability to do something.

,

First, let’s look at the rules for how to create potential form, and then how we can use it in a sentence.

,

Simply remove the final る (ru) and replace with られる (rareru).

,

食べる -> 食べられる (taberu -> taberareru)

,

To eat -> To be able to eat

,

Change the final “u” to be an “e” instead, and then add る (ru).

,

Ex) む (mu) becomes め (me).

,

飲む -> 飲める (nomu -> nomeru)

,

To drink -> To be able to drink

,

立つ -> 立てる (tatsu -> tateru)

,

To stand -> To be able to stand

,

する -> できる (suru -> dekiru)

,

To do -> To be able to do

,

くる -> これる (kuru -> koreru)

,

To come -> To be able to come

,

When using potential form, the particle を (o/wo) is often changed to が (ga) instead.

,

すしを食べる。

,

sushi o taberu.

,

I eat sushi.

,

Will change to..

,

すしが食べられる。

,

sushi ga taberareru

,

I can eat sushi.

,

You can use either を (o/wo) or が (ga) with most verbs, but when used with できる (dekiru), you must always use が (ga).

,

Be careful to not confuse this with 受身形 (ukemi) passive voice, where many conjugations may be similar.

,

Click the image to download the flashcard.
Download all N4 grammar flashcards.

,

Download our complete
JLPT N4 Grammar Master E-book.

さ.name: さ (sa)
さ.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: さ (sa). Meaning: -ness​ ; nominalizer for adjectives.

,

Adding さ after an adjective it turns it into a Noun.

,

It is very similar to English words ending in -ess, for example:

,

やさしい (yasashii) “nice / kind”

,

やさしさ (yasashisa) “nice-ness / kindness”

,

さ (sa) is also often used for something measurable, for example:

,

長い (nagai) “long”

,

長さ (nagasa) “length”

,

Download all N4 grammar flashcards.

,

examples.en: The space of her room is about 6 tatami mats (unit of measurement for Japanese rooms).
examples.ja: 彼女の部屋の広さは畳で６畳くらいです。

examples.en: I want to introduce to everyone the deliciousness of this food.
examples.ja: この料理の美味しさを皆さんに紹介したいです。

examples.en: I love how interesting he is (his interesting-ness literally).
examples.ja: 彼の面白さが大好きです。

examples.en: The size is different, but the quality is the same.
examples.ja: 大きさは違うけど質は同じですよ。

から作る（からつくる）.name: から作る (kara tsukuru)
から作る（からつくる）.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: から作る 【からつくる】(kara tsukuru). Meaning: made from; made with.

,

作る (tsukuru) can be proceeded with either から or で.

,

作る is also often changed to 作られる / 作られている (tsukurareru / tsukurarete iru) passive form.

examples.ja: このつくえは木で作られています。

examples.en: This bridge was made from stones.
examples.ja: この橋は石から作られている。

examples.ja: 日本酒は米から作られます。

examples.en: I made this jelly from apple juice.
examples.ja: このゼリーはリンゴジュースで作った。

と言われている（といわれている）.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: と言われている 【といわれている】(to iwarete iru). Meaning: it is said that~.

examples.en: He is said to be a genius.

examples.en: It's being said that he will quit next month.
examples.ja: 彼は来月に退職すると言われている。

examples.en: It is said that women live longer than men.
examples.ja: 女性は男性より長生きだと言われている。

examples.en: Her mother is said to be a famous writer.

examples.en: He is said to have had a weak body when he was young.

examples.en: It is said that they are going to get married by the end of the year.

examples.en: It is said that nothing is more important than health.

examples.en: It is said that Friday the 13th is an unlucky day.
examples.ja: 13日の金曜日は不吉な日だと言われている。

させられる.name: させられる (saserareru)
させられる.definition: causative-passive; to be made to do something
させられる.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: させられる (saserareru). Meaning: causative-passive form; to be made to do something.

,

The technical term for this grammar point is ‘causative-passive’, or in Japanese ‘受け身動詞’ (ukemi doushi).

,

To use, you must first conjugate the causative form. See lesson for させる (saseru) Causative Form.

,

Click the image to download the flashcard.
Download all N4 grammar flashcards.

,

Download our complete
JLPT N4 Grammar Master E-book.

examples.en: I was forced to quit my job.
examples.ja: 仕事を辞めさせられた。

examples.en: My son was expelled from school.
examples.ja: 息子は退学させられた。

examples.en: She made me wait over 2 hours.
examples.ja: 彼女に2時間も待たされた。

examples.en: That movie makes you think.
examples.ja: その映画は考えさせられる。

examples.en: Every day, my mother forces me to eat vegetables.
examples.ja: 毎日母に野菜を食べさせられる。

examples.en: My fiance's father made me to drink alcohol with him.
examples.ja: フィアンセのお父さんにお酒を飲ませられた。

examples.en: I am made to do my homework everyday by my parents.
examples.ja: 親に毎日宿題をさせられる。

examples.en: On weekends, I am forced to help out with the family restaurant.
examples.ja: 週末には家族のレストランで手伝わせられる。

examples.en: He was forced to transfer from one company branch to another.
examples.ja: 彼は支店から支店へと転勤させられた。

させられる.usage: Verb (causative form させる)られるくるこさせられるやるやらせられる

きっと.name: きっと (kitto)
きっと.definition: surely; undoubtedly; almost certainly; most likely
きっと.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: きっと (kitto). Meaning: surely; undoubtedly; almost certainly; most likely.

,

Click the image to download the flashcard.
Download all N4 grammar flashcards.

,

Download our complete
JLPT N4 Grammar Master E-book.

examples.en: It will likely rain tomorrow.
examples.ja: 明日はきっと雨でしょう。

examples.en: I am certain she will come.
examples.ja: 彼女はきっと来るよ。

examples.en: You studied really hard, so I'm sure tomorrow's test will be fine!
examples.ja: がんばって勉強したから、きっと明日のテストは大丈夫だよ。

examples.en: It will most likely be sunny tomorrow.
examples.ja: 明日は、きっと晴れるでしょう。

examples.en: He's my best friend, so I'm positive he will help me.
examples.ja: 彼は私の親友だから、きっと私を助けてくれる。

examples.en: This job's salary is low, so surely no one will want to do it.
examples.ja: この仕事の給料は低いからきっと誰でもやりたくない。

examples.en: I've never seen that person before, so they're most likely a new student.
examples.ja: あの人は見たことないから、きっと新しい学生だ。

examples.en: She doesn't like parties, so I'm almost certain she won't come to tomorrow's party.
examples.ja: 彼女はパーティーが好きじゃないから、きっと明日のパーティーも来ないと思う。

examples.en: Today is our wedding anniversary, so surely my husband will head home early.
examples.ja: 今日は結婚記念日だから、主人はきっと早く帰ると思います。

頃（ころ / ごろ）.name: 頃 (koro / goro)
頃（ころ / ごろ）.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: 頃 【 ころ / ごろ 】 (koro / goro). Meaning: around; about; when.

,

Both the kanji version and hiragana versions are frequently used.

,

Click the image to download the flashcard.
Download all N4 grammar flashcards.

,

JLPT N4 Grammar Master E-book.

examples.en: Can you come by my place around eight p.m.?
examples.ja: 夜の8時ごろ、うちに来てもらえるか？

examples.en: I am very busy these days.
examples.ja: 私はこのころとても忙しいのです。

examples.en: I traveled alone for the first time when I was young.
examples.ja: 私は若いころ初めての一人旅をしました。

examples.en: OK, I’ll pick you up round about nine thirty. Is that right?
examples.ja: じゃ、僕は9時半ごろ迎えに来ればいいですね。

examples.en: Did you ever experience bullying when you were a child?
examples.ja: あなたは子供のころ、いじめにあったことはある？

examples.en: Around what time will you be expecting dinner?
examples.ja: 夕食は何時ごろになさいますか？

examples.en: It had been a very old song when I was young.
examples.ja: それはわたしが子どものころに歌ったたいへん古い歌だった。

examples.en: We come in at 7 o’clock in the morning. We work right through, and we leave at about half past 10 at night.
examples.ja: 私たちは朝７時に出勤します。それからずっと仕事で、夜１０時半頃に店を出ます。

examples.en: I didn’t go to school as a child and I traveled a lot with my parents.
examples.ja: 私は子どもの頃、学校へ行かず、両親と一緒にずっと移動生活をしていた。

させてください.name: させてください (sasete kudasai)
させてください.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: させてください (sasete kudasai). Meaning: please let me do.

,

This must be with a verb’s て version of させる (saseru) causative form.

,

When referring to yourself, you must use 私に (watashi ni) instead of 私は (watashi wa).

,

Click the image to download the flashcard.
Download all N4 grammar flashcards.

,

Download our complete
JLPT N4 Grammar Master E-book.

examples.en: Please allow me to ask you a question.
examples.ja: 質問させてください。

examples.en: Please let me tell you about myself.
examples.ja: 私のことをあなたに話させてください。

examples.en: I'm not feeling well, so please let me head home early.
examples.ja: ちょっと調子が悪いので、早く帰らさせてください。

examples.en: Please let me think a bit before I give you my answer.
examples.ja: 返事をする前にちょっと考えさせてください。

examples.en: Please let me help with something.
examples.ja: 私に何かお手伝いさせてください。

examples.en: She is sick today so please allow her to have the day off.
examples.ja: 彼女は今日病気なのでお休みさせてください。

examples.en: Please allow me to introduce our club activities.
examples.ja: 私に私たちの部活動について紹介させてください。

examples.en: I am not very good at English, so please let me speak in Japanese.
examples.ja: 英語が苦手なので、日本語で話しをさせてください。

examples.en: Please let me consult with you once more about this matter.
examples.ja: この件についてもう一度相談させてください。

させる.name: させる (saseru)
させる.definition: causative form; to make/let somebody do something
させる.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: させる (saseru). Meaning: causative form. This can mean either:

,

子どもに勉強をさせる。

,

kodomo ni benkyou o saseru.

,

To make children study.

,

食べさせてください。

,

tabe sasete kudasai

,

Please let me to eat.

,

You will often have to guess or assume which meaning is correct based on the context.

,

Example) To marry

,

結婚させる。

,

kekkon saseru

,

Meaning 1) to make marry

,

Meaning 2) to allow to marry

,

Click the image to download the flashcard.
Download all N4 grammar flashcards.

,

Download our complete
JLPT N4 Grammar Master E-book.

examples.en: My mother made me clean up my own room.
examples.ja: 母は私に自分の部屋を片付けさせた。

examples.en: I'll make one of my subordinates do this task.
examples.ja: この仕事は部下にやらせます。

examples.en: I didn't mean to make you cry!
examples.ja: 君を泣かせるつもりはなかった！

examples.en: Please allow me to do it.
examples.ja: 僕にやらせてください

examples.en: My son wants to watch anime, but he hasn't finished his homework, so I won't let him watch it..
examples.ja: 息子はアニメを見たがっていますが、宿題が終わっていないので、見させません。

させる.usage: Ru-verbる -> させるU-verb(ない form) ない -> せるするさせるやるやらせるくるこさせる

ことがある.name: ことがある (koto ga aru)
ことがある.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: ことがある (koto ga aru). Meaning: there are times when ~; sometimes do.

,

ことがある (koto ga aru) is used to say:

It must be used with a non-past verb.

examples.en: Sometimes I go to play tennis with my girlfriend.

examples.en: Sometimes I commute to work by bicycle.
examples.ja: たまに自転車で通勤することがある。

examples.en: Sometimes I fall asleep during meetings.
examples.ja: 私は会議中でも、寝てしまうことがある。

examples.en: There are times when I feel like quitting my job.

examples.ja: たまに人の名前を忘れることがあります。

examples.en: There's something I'd like to talk to you about
examples.ja: 話したいことがある。

examples.en: This week there are a lot of things for me to do.

続ける（つづける）.name: 続ける (tsuzukeru)
続ける（つづける）.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: 続ける 【つづける】(tsuzukeru). Meaning: continue to; keen on~.

,

This is used to express continuous action, or to show someone is keen on doing something.

,

It can be freely conjugated to use in current, future, and past tense.

examples.en: It's been raining nonstop since yesterday.

examples.en: Prices will likely continue to rise.

ことができる.name: ことができる (koto ga dekiru)
ことができる.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: ことができる (koto ga dekiru). Meaning: can; able to; not able to.

,

ことができる (koto ga dekiru) is used to say something can be done or is able to be done.

,

ことになる.name: ことになる (koto ni naru)
ことになる.definition: It has been decided that..; it turns out that..
ことになる.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: ことになる (koto ni naru). Meaning: It has been decided that..; it turns out that..

,

ことになる (koto ni naru) is used used to express something that has been decided or determined by factors outside of one’s own resolve. Though sometimes it can be an indirect way to say something that may indeed be one’s own resolve..

,

If you want to express something that has been determined by one’s own resolve, you can use the similar grammar point ことにする (koto ni suru) instead.

,

NOTE, this grammar point often uses the past version of なる (naru) to express that something has already been decided:

,

だ・です.name: だ・です (da / desu)
だ・です.definition: to be (am, is, are, were, used to)
だ・です.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: だ (da) & です (desu). Meaning: to be (am, is, are, were, used to).

,

Let’s look at some of the different ways this grammar can be used.

,

Example A)　です

,

私はクリスです。

,

watashi wa kurisu desu.

,

I am Chris.

,

This literally translates to “I Chris am”. Remember that Japanese uses SOV (subject-object-verb), rather than SVO like English. This may be strange at first, but it will become natural after some practice.

,

Example B)　だ

,

私はクリスだ。

,

watashi wa kurisu da.

,

I am Chris.

,

だ (da) and です (desu) have the exact same meaning, but です (desu) is more polite, so when in doubt it’s best to always use です (desu).

,

Example C) to be: am, is, are

,

私の名前はクリスです。

,

watashi no namae wa kurisu desu.

,

My name is Chris.

,

だ (da) and です (desu) can mean am, is and are. There is no distinction like in English, so it works for everything. This is one of the easier points of Japanese grammar.

,

Example D) They are

,

彼らは3年生です。

,

karera wa san nensei desu.

,

They are 3rd year students.

,

,

When you want to say something “used to be” (was, were, used to, etc), you’ll want to use this conjugation. Once again, there is a casual form だった (datta), and the more polite でした (deshita).

,

Example E) Was

,

昨日はとてもきれいな日だった。

,

kinou wa totemo kireina hi datta.

,

Yesterday was a very beautiful day.

,

Example F) Used to

,

子どものとき、甘いものが好きでした。

,

kodomo no toki, amai mono ga suki deshita.

,

When I was a child, I used to like sweets.

,

Download all N5 grammar flashcards.

,

JLPT N5 Grammar Master E-book.

で.name: で (de)
で.definition: in; at; on; by; with; via
で.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: で (de) has various meanings, including in; at; on; by; with; via; and even because.

,

The meaning changes based on the context of the sentence. Let’s look at some basic examples.

,

Indicates the place where an action occurs. In this pattern, the preceding noun must be a location.

,

Indicates a means or method. Similar to “by”, “with”, or “via”

,

Indicates a total amount of something (time, money, etc).

,

This meaning is very similar to the grammar ので (node)

,

Download all N5 grammar flashcards.

,

JLPT N5 Grammar Master E-book.

なくてもいい.name: なくてもいい (naku temo ii)
なくてもいい.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: なくてもいい (naku temo ii). Meaning: don’t have to; it’s OK to not do.

,

The も (mo) is optional and may be used as なくていい (nakute ii).

,

This grammar is an extension of ても (temo) and てもいいです (temo ii desu).

,

や.name: や (ya)
や.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: や (ya). Meaning: and; or; connecting particle. The particle や is used to list multiple things and imply there are other items that could be included in the list.

,

It is very similar to the grammar と (to), which also means “and”. The main difference being と only lists the actual items listed, and や implies the listed items are not complete.

,

Download all N5 grammar flashcards.

JLPT N5 Grammar Master E-book.

だろう.name: だろう (darou)
だろう.definition: I think; it seems; probably; right?
だろう.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: だろう (darou). Meaning: I think; it seems; probably; right?

,

Although there are many different meanings, which may seem confusing, it is usually easy to understand from context. Let’s look at some basic examples.

,

BTW, sometimes this grammar is shortened to just だろ (daro), but the meaning is the same.

,

Example A)

,

嘘だろう。

,

uso darou.

,

You’re kidding (surely that’s a lie)

,

That’s a lie, right?

,

This method can express either confidence that it is likely a lie, or express that you are asking for confirmation, though it depends on the tone of the speaker and the situation.

,

Example 2)

,

雨が降るだろう。

,

ame ga furu darou.

,

It seems like it’s going to rain.

,

I think it’s going to rain.

,

Like the previous example, the meaning changes depending on the speaker’s tone and the situation. When spoken in a questioning type of tone, it is asking for confirmation from whoever the speaker is talking to. Otherwise, it expresses what the speaker is thinking; in this case thinking that it is likely to rain.

,

Example C) showing speculation

,

それは何だろう。

,

sore wa nan darou?

,

I wonder what that is..

,

Download all N5 grammar flashcards.

,

JLPT N5 Grammar Master E-book.

んです.name: んです (ndesu)
んです.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: んです (ndesu) & んだ (nda). Meaning: to explain something; show emphasis.

,

んです (ndesu) has the same meaning as です (desu), but is different in that it feels a bit more personal since it is used to explain something, give reasoning, or to emphasize something.

,

It is exactly the same as のです (no desu), which is a bit more polite / formal.

,

For example, can you tell the difference between 1, 2 and 3?

,

1 is simply stating a fact. That it/something is hot.

,

2 is also stating a fact, but carries a bit more emphasis as the speaker may be answering/asking a question or explaining their feelings.

,

3 is the same as 2, but the more casual version.

,

Click the image to download the flashcard.
Download all N5 grammar flashcards.

,

Download our complete
JLPT N5 Grammar Master E-book.

でしょう.name: でしょう (deshou)
でしょう.definition: I think; it seems; probably; right?
でしょう.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: でしょう (deshou). Meaning: I think; it seems; probably; right?

,

Although there are many different meanings, which may seem confusing, it is usually easy to understand from context.

,

Some important notes:

,

Example A)

,

明日は雨が降るでしょう。

,

ashita wa ame ga furu deshou.

,

It will probably rain tomorrow.

,

I think it will rain tomorrow.

,

Example B)

,

先生はまもなく来るでしょう。

,

sensei wa mamonaku kuru deshou.

,

Sensei (the teacher) will probably come soon.

,

Example C) showing speculation

,

それは何でしょう。

,

sore wa nan deshou?

,

I wonder what that is..

,

ね.name: ね (ne)
ね.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: ね (ne). Meaning: the particle ね is a sentence ending particle that is used to confirm something to someone. Similar to “right?” or “don’t you think so?” or “eh?”.

,

Here’s a basic example that is very commonly used in Japanese summers.

,

今日はあついですね。

,

kyou wa atsui desu ne.

,

It’s hot today (don’t you agree?)

,

どうして.name: どうして (doushite)
どうして.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: どうして (doushite). Meaning: why; for what reason; how.

,

Example A) why

,

,

doushite konakatta

,

Why did you not come?

,

Example B) how / method

,

この字はどうして書くんですか？

,

kono ji wa doushite kaku n desuka?

,

How do you write this character?

,

に/へ.name: に/へ (ni/e)
に/へ.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: に (ni) & へ (e) . Meaning: to (indicates direction / destination).

,

Both are interchangeable.

,

学校に行く。

,

gakkou ni iku.

,

To go to school.

,

学校へ行く。

,

gakkou e iku.

,

To go to school.

,

に can also be used to say in, at, on, etc.. See full lesson for lesson for に (ni).

JLPT N5 Grammar Master E-book.

の.name: の (no)
の.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: の (no). Meaning: の is a particle used to indicate possession. It is similar to [‘s].

,

For example, [A]の[B] would mean [B] belong’s to [A].

,

私のペン。

,

watashi no pen.

,

My pen.

が.name: が (ga)
が.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: が (ga). Meaning: the particle が has two main meanings, one as a subject marker particle, and the other as however; but.

,

が is used to mark a subject in a sentence. It is very similar to the particle は (wa) Topic Marker.

,

See examples 1~5

,

When placed in between two sentences, が can also mean “however” or “but”.

,

See examples 6~9

,

Download all N5 grammar flashcards.

,

Download our complete
JLPT N5 Grammar Master E-book.

examples.ja: コンビニが近くにあります。

examples.ja: 彼は借金がある。

examples.en: I deeply apologize, but today we have no more seats available. (we are fully booked)
examples.ja: 恐れ入りますが、本日は満席です。

が.usage:
Usage 1: subject marker
subject + がUsage 2: however; but
Sentence 1 + が + Sentence 2

のです.name: のです (no desu)
のです.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: のです (no desu) & のだ (noda). Meaning: to explain something; show emphasis.

,

のです (no desu) has the same meaning as です (desu), but is different in that it feels a bit more personal since it is used to explain something, give reasoning, or to emphasize something.

,

It is exactly the same as んです (ndesu), which is a bit more casual.

,

For example, can you tell the difference between 1, 2 and 3?

,

1 is simply stating a fact. That it/something is hot.

,

2 is also stating a fact, but carries a bit more emphasis as the speaker may be answering/asking a question or explaining their feelings.

,

3 is the same as 2, but the more casual version.

,

NOTE: This grammar is only used with Nouns when asking questions.

,

クルーズはいい先生なのですか？

,

kuruuzu wa ii sensei nano desu ka?

,

Is Cruise a good teacher?

,

Click the image to download the flashcard.
Download all N5 grammar flashcards.

,

Download our complete
JLPT N5 Grammar Master E-book.

examples.ja: 何を言いたいのですか。

examples.ja: あなたは優しいのですね。

examples.en: You're going to school today, right?

がほしい.name: がほしい (ga hoshii)
がほしい.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: がほしい / が欲しい (ga hoshii). Meaning: to want something.This grammar is used to show you want something.

,

Simply add がほしい after a noun.

,

これがほしい -> kore ga hoshii -> I want this.

,

There is also a kanji version が欲しい, but it is commonly used with just hiragana:

,

Download all N5 grammar flashcards.

,

JLPT N5 Grammar Master E-book.

examples.ja: もっとお金が欲しいです。

examples.en: I want a girlfriend.
examples.ja: 彼女がほしい。

examples.en: I want a lot of money. (it's OK to split が and ほしい)
examples.ja: お金がたくさんほしい。

examples.en: How many children do you want to have?
examples.ja: 何人子どもがほしいですか？

examples.en: I want the new GoPro camera!
examples.ja: 新しいGoProカメラが欲しいです！

examples.en: I want to have my own house one day.
examples.ja: いつか自分の家が欲しいです。

examples.en: What I want is freedom.
examples.ja: 私が欲しいものは自由です。

examples.en: I want a car made in Japan.
examples.ja: 日本で作られた車が欲しい。

examples.en: Work is too busy lately, I want some time to relax.

examples.en: I want a computer like the one he has.
examples.ja: 彼が持っているみたいなパソコンが欲しい。

のが上手（のがじょうず）.name: のが上手 (no ga jouzu)
のが上手（のがじょうず）.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: のが上手 / のがじょうずです (no ga jouzu desu). Meaning: to be good at doing something.

,

Example A)

,

Simply add のが上手 (no ga jouzu) after a verb in its dictionary form to say you are good at that action.

,

スポーツをするのが上手ですね。

,

supootsu o suru no ga jouzu desu ne.

,

You are very good at sports.

,

This grammar is usually written with its kanji form.

,

To say the opposite “bad at”, use のが下手 (no ga heta)

,

Click the image to download the flashcard.
Download all N5 grammar flashcards.

,

Download our complete
JLPT N5 Grammar Master E-book.

examples.en: You're good at teaching.
examples.ja: あなたは教えるのが上手です。

examples.en: He's good at singing.
examples.ja: 彼は歌うのが上手だ。

examples.en: She's good at playing piano.
examples.ja: 彼女はピアノを弾くのが上手。

examples.en: You're very good at using chopsticks.
examples.ja: あなたはお箸を使うのが上手ですね。

examples.en: I'm not very good at speaking Japanese..
examples.ja: 私はそんなに日本語を話すのが上手ではない。

examples.ja: 私は母ほど料理をするのが上手ではありません。

examples.en: I'm not good at managing time..
examples.ja: 時間を管理するのが上手ではない。

のが下手（のがへた）.name: のが下手 (no ga heta)
のが下手（のがへた）.definition: to be bad at doing something
のが下手（のがへた）.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: のが下手 【のがへた】(no ga heta). Meaning: to be bad at doing something.

,

Example A)

,

Simply add のが下手 (no ga heta) after a verb in its dictionary form to say you are good at that action.

,

スポーツをするのがへただ。

,

supootsu wo suru no ga heta da.

,

I am bad at playing sports.

,

This grammar is usually written with its kanji form.

,

To say the opposite “good at”, use のが上手 (no ga jouzu)

,

,

JLPT N5 Grammar Master E-book.

がいます.name: がいます (ga imasu)
がいます.definition: there is; to be; is (living things)
がいます.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: がいます (ga imasu) & がいる (ga iru). Meaning: used to say there is or something is for LIVING things.

,

The verb いる (iru) comes from 居る (iru), which is the verb for to be (for living things). However, when used in this grammar form, the hiragana form is used instead of the kanji form.

,

Let’s look at some basic examples.

,

ほうがいい.name: ほうがいい (hou ga ii)
ほうがいい.definition: had better; it'd be better to; should~
ほうがいい.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: 方がいい / (ほうがいい) (hou ga ii). Meaning: had better; it’d be better to; should~

Both the kanji and hiragana version can be used: 方がいい / ほうがいい .

,

itta hou ga ii.

,

,

行かないほうがいい。

,

ikanai hou ga ii.

,

You shouldn’t go.

のが好き（のがすき）.notes:

の中で[A]が一番（のなかで[A]がいちばん）.name: の中で[A]が一番 (no naka de [A] ga ichiban)
の中で[A]が一番（のなかで[A]がいちばん）.definition: out of this group, [A] is best
の中で[A]が一番（のなかで[A]がいちばん）.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: の中で[A]が一番 【のなかで[A]がいちばん】 (no naka de [A] ga ichiban). Meaning: out of this group, [A] is best.

い-adjectives.name: い-adjectives (i-adjectives)
い-adjectives.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: い-adjectives (i-adjectives), also known as い形容詞 (i keiyoushi).

,

There are two kinds of adjectives in Japanese, i-adjectives (い形容詞) and na-adjectives (な形容詞).

,

Unlike na-adjectives, i-adjectives have unique conjugation rules that you must learn. Let’s start with a basic example.

,

Let’s start with a basic adjective, あつい (atsui) which means hot.

,

今日はあついです。

,

kyou wa atsui desu.

,

It is hot today.

,

今日はあつくないです。

,

kyou wa atsukunai desu.

,

It isn’t hot today.

,

昨日はあつかった。

,

kinou wa atsukatta.

,

It was hot yesterday.

,

昨日はあつくなかった。

,

kinou wa atsukunakatta.

,

It was not hot yesterday.

,

Also see lesson on な-adjectives (な形容詞).

,

Click the image to download the flashcard.
Download all N5 grammar flashcards.

,

Download our complete
JLPT N5 Grammar Master E-book.
い-adjectives.usage:
presentいpresent negativeくない
くありませんpastかったpast negativeくなかった
くありませんでした

を.name: を (o / wo )
を.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: を (o / wo). Meaning: object marker particle. The particle を is used to indicate the target of a verb, and is therefore called the “object marker”.

,

The standard pattern for use is:

,

In this example, を is marking the preceding noun (meat) as the subject for the verb (to eat).

,

The romaji version is commonly written as just “o”, but is more of a “wo” sound.

,

お / ご.name: お / ご (o / go)
お / ご.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: お / ご (o / go). Meaning: polite marker; honorific prefix particle.

,

Putting お (o) or ご (go) in front of nouns or adjectives makes the word more polite.

,

For some vocabulary words (like お茶 ocha), it is standard to use this prefix and it is considered rude to not use it.

,

NOTE: お (o) is mostly used with words of Japanese origin, and ご (go) is mostly used with words of Chinese origin, though there are some exceptions.

,

At more advanced levels, the kanji 御 may be used, which can be read as either お or ご.

,

JLPT N5 Grammar Master E-book.

一緒に（いっしょに）.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: 一緒に「いっしょに」 (issho ni). Meaning: together.

,

This grammar can be used to talk about doing things together.

,

Example A) 一緒に

,

issho ni ikimasen ka?

,

,

Example B) with と

,

Often, it is preceded with と to show with whom.

,

彼女と一緒にレストランへ行きます。

,

kanojo to issho ni resutoran e ikimasu.

,

I’m going together with my girlfriend to a restaurant.

じゃない・ではない.name: じゃない・ではない (janai / dewa nai)
じゃない・ではない.definition: to not be (am not; is not; are not)
じゃない・ではない.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: じゃない (janai) & ではない (dewa nai). Meaning: to not be (am not; is not; are not).

,

Make sure you review “to be” Part 1, before starting this lesson: だ・です (da / desu).

,

Both じゃない and ではない are at the casual level, and can be interchanged freely.

,

Example A)

,

私はともこ先生ではない。

,

watashi wa tomoko sensei dewanai.

,

I am not Tomoko-sensei.

,

This literally translates to “I Tomoko-sensei am not”. Remember that Japanese uses SOV (subject-object-verb), rather than SVO like English. This may be strange at first, but it will become natural after some practice.

,

Example B)

,

私は日本人じゃないよ。

,

watashi wa nihonjin janai yo.

,

I am not Japanese.

,

Using the more polite form is simple. Just drop the ない (nai) and change to ありません (arimasen):

,

,

Casual Past Tense:

,

Polite Past Tense:

,

There are many different conjugations that can be used, but within the same politeness level, they can be interchanged freely. Let’s look at some basic examples:

,

Past Tense Example A)

,

私はそれをやるべきじゃなかった。

,

watashi wa sore o yaru beki ja nakatta.

,

I should not have done that.

,

Past Tense Example B)

,

私は昨日、暇ではありませんでした。

,

watashi wa kinou, hima dewa arimasen deshita.

,

I was not free yesterday (had no free time).

,

,

Click the image to download the flashcard.
Download all N5 grammar flashcards.

,

Download our complete
JLPT N5 Grammar Master E-book.

,

方（かた）.name: 方 (kata)
方（かた）.definition: the way of doing something; how to do
方（かた）.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: 方 [かた] (kata). Meaning: the way of doing something; how to do.

,

から.name: から (kara)
から.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: から (kara) / だから (da kara). Meaning: because; since; from.

,

This grammar can be used in two different ways to express two different meanings. Both forms are very commonly used in Japanese, so it is important to understand how to use both forms and to be able to comprehend them correctly.

,

Let’s look at some specific examples below:

,

The first meaning expresses a cause and effect type relationship. Because of [A], [B].

,

明日テストがあるから、今夜勉強つもりだ。

,

ashita tesuto ga aru kara, konya benkyou tsumori da.

,

Since I have a test tomorrow, I plan to study tonight.

,

Verbs can also be used in past tense form

,

今朝テストがあったから、今はちょっとつかれた。

,

kesa tesuto ga atta kara, ima wa chotto tsukareta.

,

I had a test this morning, so I’m a bit tired now.

,

Nouns change to だから (dakara)

,

大事なしけんだから、がんばる！

,

daiji na shiken dakara, ganbaru!

,

This is a very important test, so I will do my best!

,

な-adjectives also use だから (dakara)

,

あの人はいつもとてもしずかだから、一度も話したことがない。

,

ano hito wa itsumo totemo shizuka dakara, ichido mo hanashita koto ga nai.

,

That person is always really quiet, so I haven’t ever talked to them.

,

い-adjectives use the regular から (kara) form

,

暑いから、窓を開けてください。

,

atsui kara, mado o akete kudasai.

,

It’s pretty hot, so could you please open the window?

,

,

The second meaning does not imply a cause and effect relationship like meaning 1. Instead, it focuses on what comes before から (kara).

,

[A]から = From/since [A],… (note that the order is reversed compared to English)

,

It can be used to express something from a person

,

このシャツは彼女からもらった。

,

kono shatsu wa kanojo kara moratta.

,

I got this shirt from my girlfriend.

,

It can also express from/since a location/time

,

生まれた時からアメリカに住んでいる。

,

umareta toki kara amerika ni sundeiru.

,

I have been living in America since I was born.

,

Another example

,

17時からアルバイトがある。

,

juu nana ji kara arubaito ga aru.

,

I’ve got my part time job from 5pm.

,

だから can be interchanged with ですから to be a bit more polite.

,

たい.name: たい (tai)
たい.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: たい (tai). Meaning: want to do something.

,

To use this grammar point, add it at the end of the verb stem
たべます -> たべたい
I eat -> I want to eat

,

すしを食べたい。

,

sushi o tabetai.

,

I want to eat sushi.

,

たい (tai) can be conjugated to be used in negative and past tense as well.

,

すしを食べたくない。

,

sushi o tabetakunai

,

I do not want to eat sushi.

,

すしを食べたかった。

,

sushi o tabetakatta.

,

I wanted to eat sushi.

,

This is mostly ONLY for first person use, but there are some situations where it’s OK to use for second person:

,

Example A) when quoting others

,

田中さんがすしを食べたいんだって。

,

tanaka-san ga sushi o tabetai ndatte.

,

Tanaka-san said he wants to eat Sushi.

,

Example B) when asking a question

,

何を食べたいですか？

,

nani o tabetai desuka?

,

What do you want to eat?

,

To say someone wants to do something in 3rd person without quoting them, use たがる (tagaru) instead.

,

まだ.name: まだ (mada)
まだ.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: まだ (mada). Meaning: still; not yet.

,

Example A) Verb

,

まだ寝ているの？

,

mada neteiru no?

,

You’re still sleeping?

,

Example B) Noun

,

まだ高校生です。

,

mada koukou sei desu.

,

I’m still a high school student.

,

まだまだ can also be used for extra emphasis.

,

たり～たり.name: たり～たり (tari~tari)
たり～たり.definition: do such things as A and B
たり～たり.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: たり～たり (tari~tari). Meaning: do such things as A and B.

,

You can use たり～たり when you want to list multiple examples. ex) “do such things as [A], [B], etc..”

,

It is possible to only use it once and list only one example. You’re basically making a list of different activities / traits, so it’s commonly used in situations like:

,

ている.name: ている (te iru)
ている.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: ている (te iru). Meaning: the progressive tense of a verb which shows that something is currently happening or ongoing.

,

There are a couple different ways it can be used, including:

,

This grammar point requires you convert the verb to て-form. After you do that, all you do is add いる at the end. In case you need it, here is a reminder on how to conjugate て-form. If not, skip ahead to the examples.

,

Example a)

,

Example b)

,

As you can see, each verb changes to a current/continuous state of doing.

,

However, as introduced in the beginning of this lesson, there are 5 different ways this grammar can be used. Let’s dive into each one in more detail below..

,

,

This is the most basic meaning, which shows that you are currently doing something at this moment.

,

Example 1.1)

,

昼ご飯を食べている。

,

hiru gohan o tabe teiru.

,

currently eating lunch now.

,

Example 1.2) Negative form

,

宿題をやっていない。

,

shukudai o yatte inai.

,

currently not doing homework.

,

ていない is the negative version of ている.

,

Example 1.3) Polite form

,

お母さんと電話をしています。

,

okaasan to denwa o shite imasu.

,

I am currently on the phone with my mom.

,

,

This meaning shows that you are currently doing something and have been doing so up until now.

,

Example 2.1)

,

先生の話を聞いているの？

,

sensei no hanashi o kiite iru no?

,

Are you listening to what the teacher is saying?

,

Have you been listening to what the teacher is saying?

,

Example 2.2)

,

5年間日本語を勉強しています。

,

go nenkan nihongo o benkyou shite imasu.

,

I have been studying Japanese for 5 years.

,

,

This meaning shows what you are doing now in general, not just this particular moment.

,

Example 3.1)

,

面白い本を読んでいる。

,

omoshiroi hon o yonde iru.

,

I am reading (currently or in general) an interesting book.

,

This example can either mean currently at this particular moment or currently as in “lately”. It depends on the context of the conversation.

,

Example 3.2)

,

日本で日本語を勉強しています。

,

nihon de nihongo o benkyou shite imasu.

,

I am studying Japanese in Japan.

,

This example is more obvious that it is not just in this particular moment, but rather describing one’s current situation.

,

,

This meaning shows habitual behavior or can be used when talking about something that frequently happens.

,

Example 4.1)

,

毎日、寝る前にマンガを読んでいる。

,

mainichi, neru mae ni manga o yonde iru.

,

I read manga every day before I sleep.

,

Example 4.2)

,

いつも自転車で通勤している。

,

itsumo jitensha de tsukin shite iru.

,

I always commute by bicycle.

,

,

This can be used to describe the current state of something, what something looks like, or that something was left in a certain state.

,

Example 5.1)

,

彼はお父さんと似ている。

,

kare wa otou-san to nite iru.

,

He looks (seems) like his father.

,

Example 5.2)

,

ドアが開いている。

,

doa ga aite iru.

,

The door has been left open.

,

This translates to the door is open, but the focus is also on the fact that the door has been left open.

,

Example 5.3)

,

今日は食堂がとても混んでいる。

,

kyou wa shokudou ga totemo konde iru.

,

The cafeteria is very crowded today.

,

Note that this example (and others) may cross over multiple categories. This is the same as the progressive tense, that it is “currently” crowded, but at the same time this is also describing the state of something, so it applies to both meanings.

,

In summary, ている (te iru) has numerous meanings, including:

,

Often in conversation the い will be dropped to become てる. This is only for casual conversations.

,

てある.name: てある (te aru)
てある.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: てある (te aru). Meaning: is/has been done (resulting state).

,

This is used when something is intentionally done and you can see the resulting state of that action. It is similar to using past tense form, but different in that it places emphasis on the action being done intentionally and the end result still being visible.

,

This grammar point requires you convert the verb to て-form. After you do that, all you do is add ある at the end. In case you need it, here is a reminder on how to conjugate て-form. If not, skip ahead to the examples.

,

This example will focus on the difference between using past form and てある (te aru) form.

,

1.1) Using 作った

,

明日の弁当はもう作った。

,

ashita no bentou wa mou tsukutta.

,

I (have) already made tomorrow’s bento (lunch).

,

1.2) Using 作ってある

,

明日の弁当はもう作ってある。

,

ashita no bentou wa mou tsukutte aru.

,

Tomorrow’s bento (lunch) has been prepared already.

,

At first glance, these sentences may seem very similar in meaning, but there are some key differences you should be aware of.

,

Example 1.1 simply says that the task was done. Example 1.2 does that as well, but also expresses that the task was done intentionally and focuses on the result of the action. In this case, that the bento lunch has been prepared and is ready.

,

Example 2)

,

ドアが開けてある。

,

doa ga akete aru.

,

The door has been left open (intentionally).

,

In this case, it’s a bit more clear that the focus is on the end result. Not on the action of opening the door, but that the door has been left open.

,

Example 3) てあった (te atta) past tense

,

保存してあったファイルが消えてしまった。

,

hozon shite atta fairu ga kiete shimatta.

,

The file I had saved (prepared) was deleted.

,

This case focuses on the preparation that was done; the file was already saved and prepared.

,

In summary, てある (te aru) is used to show a task that was completed with focus on:

,

This grammar can ONLY be used with transitive verbs. The form will almost always look like this:

,

Subject + (が / は / を) + transitive verb + てある

,

もう.name: もう (mou)
もう.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: もう (mou). Meaning: already; anymore; again; other.

,

もう (mou) can take on various different meanings:

,

Usually used with time or age.

,

もう9時だ。

,

mou ku ji da.

,

,

It’s already 9 o’clock.

,

Used with a negative sentence.

,

もう行かない。

,

mou ikanai.

,

,

I’m not going to go anymore.

,

This can be used for both positive and negative situations.

,

もう二度と行かない。

,

mou nidoto ikanai.

,

,

I’m never going to go again.

,

This form is usually at the beginning of a sentence to express the speaker’s irritation as they criticize something/someone. (mostly used by women)

,

もうたくさんだ。

,

mou takusan da.

,

,

I can’t take this anymore.

,

Click the image to download the flashcard.
Download all N5 grammar flashcards.

,

Download our complete
JLPT N5 Grammar Master E-book.

な-adjectives.name: な-adjectives (na-adjectives)
な-adjectives.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: な-adjectives (na-adjectives), also known as な形容詞 (na keiyoushi).

,

There are two kinds of adjective in Japanese, i-adjectives (い形容詞) and na-adjectives (な形容詞).

,

The na-adjective is very simple to learn because it acts essentially like a noun and the form does not change much. Let’s look at some basic examples.

,

Let’s start with a basic adjective, 元気 【げんき】 (genki) which means energetic.

,

その子はげんきだ。

,

sono ko wa genki da.

,

That child is energetic.

,

When a na-adjective is placed before a noun, a な is added at the end of the adjective.

,

かれはげんきな子だね。

,

kare wa genki na ko da ne.

,

He is an energetic child.

,

その子はげんきじゃないね。

,

sono ko wa genki janai ne.

,

That child is not very energetic.

,

その子はとてもげんきだったね。

,

sono ko wa totemo genki datta ne.

,

That child was really energetic.

,

かれはあまりげんきじゃなかったね。

,

kare wa amari genki janakatta ne.

,

He wasn’t very energetic.

,

Also see lesson on い-adjectives (い形容詞).

,

Click the image to download the flashcard.
Download all N5 grammar flashcards.

,

Download our complete
JLPT N5 Grammar Master E-book.

ないでください.name: ないでください (naide kudasai)
ないでください.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: ないでくだあい (naide kudasai). Meaning: please don’t do.

,

This is used after a verb to request to the listener to not do something.

,

You can remove the ください (kudasai), to just say ないで (naide), which is more casual.

,

Be careful to not confuse this with the other ないで (naide) meaning.

,

,

行かないでください。

,

ika naide kudasai.

,

Please don’t go!

,

それを食べないでください。

,

sore o tabe naide kudasai.

,

Please don’t eat that.

,

Download all N5 grammar flashcards.

,

JLPT N5 Grammar Master E-book.

,

examples.en: I have to go home at 5PM.
examples.ja: 私は17時ごろ家に帰らないといけません。

examples.en: So I have to study more, don't I?
examples.ja: もっと勉強しないとだめですよね。

ないといけない.usage:
Verb (ない form) + といけない
いけません
ダメです

とても.name: とても (totemo)
とても.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: とても (totemo). Meaning: very; awfully; exceedingly​.

,

examples.en: Today is very hot, isn't it?
examples.ja: 今日はとても暑いですね。

examples.en: ichi gatsu to nigatsu wa totemo samui desu.
examples.ja: 1月と２月はとても寒いです。

examples.en: This curry is very spicy!
examples.ja: このカレーはとても辛いですね。

examples.en: They look very alike.
examples.ja: 彼らはとても似ている。

examples.en: I really love my parents.
examples.ja: 両親のことをとても愛している。

examples.en: The movie I watched yesterday was very interesting.
examples.ja: 昨日見た映画はとても面白かった。

examples.en: This book is very interesting. You should give it a read.
examples.ja: この本、とても面白いですよ。読んだ方がいい。

examples.en: He looks very tired.
examples.ja: 彼はとても疲れているように見える。

ないで.name: ないで (naide)
ないで.definition: without doing~ ; To do [B] without doing [A]
ないで.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: ないで (naide). Meaning: without doing~ ; To do [B] without doing [A]

,

If no action follows ないで, it turns into a request. See lesson ないでください (naide kudasai).

,

examples.en: I always drink coffee without putting any sugar in it.
examples.ja: コーヒーには、いつもさとうを入れないで飲みます。

examples.en: She left without bringing an umbrella.
examples.ja: 彼女はカサを持たないで出てしまった。

examples.en: Yesterday I was so tired I fell asleep without turning off the lights.
examples.ja: 昨日は疲れていて、電気を消さないで寝てしまった。

examples.en: I came to work today without eating any breakfast.
examples.ja: 今朝、朝ごはんを食べないで仕事に来ました。

examples.en: I went to bed yesterday without taking a bath/shower.
examples.ja: 昨日、お風呂に入らないで寝てしまった。

examples.en: Tomorrow is test day, so I'm gonna stay up all night and study without sleep.
examples.ja: 明日は試験なので、今夜は寝ないで勉強します。

examples.en: Lately it's pretty cool, so I go to sleep without using the AC.
examples.ja: 最近、涼しいのでエアコンをつけないで寝ます。

examples.en: I came to school without eating breakfast, so I'm pretty hungry.
examples.ja: 朝ごはんを食べないで学校に来たから、お腹がすいた。

は〜より・・・です.name: は〜より・・・です (wa ~yori... desu)
は〜より・・・です.notes:
Learn Japanese grammar: は〜より・・・です (wa ~yori… desu). Meaning: [A] is more ~ than [B]. Comparing 2 nouns. Emphasizes noun-1 [A] as being greater than noun-2 [B].

,

examples.en: Books are more interesting than movies.
examples.ja: 本は映画より面白いです。

examples.en: Today is busier than yesterday.
examples.ja: 今日は昨日より忙しいです。

examples.en: Trains are faster than buses.
examples.ja: 電車はバスより速いです。

examples.en: American's are taller than Japanese.
examples.ja: アメリカ人は日本人より背が高いです。

examples.en: Hokkaido is bigger than Taiwan.
examples.ja: 北海道は台湾より大きいです。

examples.en: Mt. Everest is taller than Mt. Fuji
examples.ja: エベレスト山は富士山より高いです。

examples.en: Kanji is more difficult than katakana.
examples.ja: 漢字はカタカナより難しいです。

は〜より・・・です.usage: Noun-1 + は + Noun-2 + より + Adj +です
